data.text:
The French Empire once controlled parts of the Middle East such as in Syria and Lebanon. Their influences are felt to this day as much as 40% of Lebanon speaks French. Is the video points out in the aftermath of World War II Syria and Lebanon were French mandates used for over 20 years. The very constitution of Lebanon is from France itself. It can also be noted that the French legacy in Lebanon as well as a Catholic legacy goes back to the eras of the crusades. There are to this day ancient Catholic churches in France that go back centuries.

French and Arabic are used in conversation by local Lebanese. This makes Lebanon sort of unique in the modern era and that the European influence is very heavily felt compared to say the gulf countries or say Iraq or Iran. It's a interesting situation because you see the French words in Arabic words used in the same sentences by local Lebanese people to this day. It may be there for that Lebanon has the most European influence at least the most French influence of all the middle eastern countries in mind.

What is the difference between Maronite and Phalangist, BTW.

One is a puppet controlled by strings and the other is the obsolete name for an animal from the genus now known as phalangers or phalangerids which are commonly known as flying opossums.

A more serious answer is that Maronites are members of a religious denomination while phalangists are members of a political party which was originally formed as a paramilitary organisation in the 1930s based on the Italian Fascist and Spanish Falange parties, hence the common name. Its official name is the Kataeb Party. There is a relationship between the two as Maronites do make up the bulk of its membership.

Wiki has a fairly decent article on the party.
